[[Oleg Mutu]] | writer = Cristian Mungiu | narrator = | starring = [[Adi Cărăuleanu]]
[[Luminița Gheorghiu]]
[[Mădălina Ghițescu]]
[[Vlad Ivanov]]
[[Anamaria Marinca]]
[[Alexandru Potocean]]
[[Laura Vasiliu]] | music = | cinematography = Oleg Mutu | editing = [[Dana Bunescu]] | distributor = BAC Films | released = {{Film date|2007|5|17|df=y|[[2007 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes]]|2007|9|14}} | runtime = 113 minutes{{cite web |url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/4-luni-3-saptamani-si-2-zile-4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-2007 |title=4 Luni, 3 Saptamani, Si 2 Zile - 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days (2007) |publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] |accessdate=31 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170901015139/http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/4-luni-3-saptamani-si-2-zile-4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-2007 |archivedate=1 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} | country = Romania | language = Romanian | budget = €600,000 | gross = $9.8 million }} '''''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days''''' ({{lang-ro|'''4 luni, 3 săptămâni și 2 zile'''}}) is a 2007 Romanian [[art film]] with [[drama film|drama]] and [[thriller film|thriller]] elements,{{refn|group=n|name="Genre"|The film has been classified as an [[art film]],{{cite web |url=https://www.salon.com/2008/01/29/mungiu/ |title=Conversations: Cristian Mungiu |last=O'hehir |first=Andrew |date=29 January 2008 |work=[[Salon.com]] |accessdate=29 September 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929183455/https://www.salon.com/2008/01/29/mungiu/ |archivedate=29 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=https://www.screendaily.com/4032548.article |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks And 2 Days (4 Luni, 3 Saptamini Si 2 Zile) |last=Fainaru |first=Dan |date=17 May 2007 |work=[[Screen Daily]] |accessdate=29 September 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929144158/https://www.screendaily.com/4032548.article |archivedate=29 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} and has also been assessed as [[drama film|drama]], [[thriller film|thriller]], [[horror film|horror]], and [[Hitchcockian|Hitchcockian suspense]].}} written and directed by [[Cristian Mungiu]] and starring [[Anamaria Marinca]], [[Laura Vasiliu]], and [[Vlad Ivanov]]. The film is set in [[Socialist Republic of Romania|Communist Romania]] in the final years of the [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]] era. It tells the story of two students, roommates in a university dormitory, who try to procure an [[Abortion law|illegal abortion]]. Inspired by an anecdote from the period and the general social historic context, it depicts the loyalty of the two friends and the struggles they face. Mungiu and cinematographer [[Oleg Mutu]] shot it in [[Bucharest]] and other Romanian locations in 2006. After making its world premiere at Cannes, ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'' made its Romanian debut on 1 June 2007, at the [[Transilvania International Film Festival]]. It opened to critical acclaim, and was noted for its [[minimalism]] and intense themes. The film won three awards at the [[2007 Cannes Film Festival]], including the [[Palme d'Or]]. It went on to win [[List of accolades received by 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days|numerous honours]], including Best Film at the [[European Film Awards]] and Romania's national [[Gopo Awards]]. ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'' became the subject of some controversy over censorship, the [[abortion debate]], and its exclusion from the [[80th Academy Awards]], but in 2016 it was named one of [[BBC's 100 Greatest Films of the 21st Century]]. ==Plot== In 1987, two university students in an unnamed [[Socialist Republic of Romania|Romanian]] town, Otilia Mihartescu and Gabriela "Găbița" Dragut, are roommates in a dormitory. When Găbița becomes pregnant, the two young women arrange a meeting with Mr. Bebe in a hotel, where he is to perform an [[abortion in Romania|illegal abortion]]. At the college dorm, Găbița and Otilia review the items they need for the day. As Găbița nervously sits and waits, Otilia [[black market|barters and buys]] soap and cigarettes from the dormitory shop. Afterwards, Otilia takes a bus to visit her boyfriend Adi, from whom she borrows money. Adi asks Otilia to visit his family that night, as it is his mother's birthday. Otilia initially declines, relenting after Adi becomes upset. Otilia heads to the Unirea hotel where Găbița has booked a room, only to be informed by an unfriendly receptionist that there is no reservation under Găbița's last name. Consequently, Otilia visits another hotel, the Tineretului, and after much begging and haggling, is able to book a room at an expensive rate. After speaking with Găbița on the telephone, Otilia goes to a rendezvous point to meet with Mr. Bebe, although he had asked Găbița that she meet him personally. Mr. Bebe grows angry upon hearing that Găbița is not at the planned hotel. At the Tineretului, Mr. Bebe discovers that Găbița's claim that her pregnancy was in its second or third month was a lie, and that it has been at least four months. This changes the procedure and also adds the risk of a murder charge. While the two women were certain that they would pay no more than 3,000 [[Romanian leu|lei]] for the abortion, it slowly becomes clear that Mr. Bebe expects both women to have sex with him. Desperate and distressed, Otilia has sex with Mr. Bebe so that he will not walk out on them, as does Găbița. Mr. Bebe then performs the abortion by injecting a probe and an unnamed fluid into Găbița's uterus, and leaves Otilia instructions on how to dispose of the fetus when it comes out. Otilia is exasperated by Găbița's lies, yet continues to help and care for her. Otilia leaves Găbița at the Tineretului to attend Adi's mother's birthday party. She is still disturbed but stays and has dinner with Adi's mother's friends, who are mostly doctors. They converse about trivial matters while Otilia and Adi remain silent. After Otilia accepts a cigarette in front of Adi's parents, one of the guests starts talking about lost values and respect for elders. Adi and Otilia retreat to his room, where she tells him about Găbița's abortion. They begin debating what would happen if it were Otilia who was pregnant, as Adi is opposed to abortion. After the argument, Otilia calls Găbița from Adi's house. Găbița does not answer, so Otilia decides to return to the hotel. When Otilia enters the hotel room Găbița is lying on the bed, and she tells Otilia that the fetus has been expelled and is in the bathroom. Otilia wraps the fetus with some towels and puts it in a bag, while Găbița asks her to bury it. Otilia walks outside, finally climbing to the top of a building, as Mr. Bebe had suggested, and dropping the bag in a trash chute. She returns to the Tineretului and finds Găbița sitting in its restaurant. Otilia sits and tells Găbița that they are never going to talk about the episode again. Otilia stares blankly at Găbița. ==Production== ===Historical background=== {{further|Decree 770}} [[File:Personality Cult Romania 1986.jpg|thumb|The film is based on [[Nicolae Ceaușescu]]'s Romania of the 1980s.]] [[Romanian Communist Party]] leader Nicolae Ceaușescu enacted the abortion law Decree 770 in 1966 in order to increase the population,{{sfn|Nasta|2016|p=169}} which was falling in the 1960s and continued to fall, aside from one year after the decree's enactment.{{sfn|Maierhofer|2017|p=161}} The procedure was permitted in only extremely limited circumstances.{{sfn|Maierhofer|2017|p=161}} The law was not based on any religious opposition to abortion,{{sfn|Gradea|2016|p=110}} but on the government's authority and control over its citizens.{{cite magazine |date=1 March 2008 |last=Porton |first=Richard |title=Not Just an Abortion Film: An Interview with Christian Mungiu |magazine=[[Cineaste (magazine)|Cineaste]] |p=35 }} Academic Adriana Gradea further argued justifications for the decree rendered a view of women as second-class citizens, with no right to be heard.{{sfn|Gradea|2016|p=110}} In the 1980s, the decree was strengthened to mandate gynecological appointments, to assess if individual women could reproduce.{{sfn|Strausz|2017|p=125}} Author Dominique Nasta judged the film to be an accurate portrait of the oppression, and on the poor state of the [[economy of Romania]] in the later days of Ceaușescu's regime.{{sfn|Nasta|2016|p=169}} During the years of Decree 770, the only available abortion methods, all illegal, could prove fatal to women, causing thousands of deaths.{{sfn|Deutscher|2017}} According to Mungiu's notes he shared with the press, the death toll was 500,000.{{cite web |url=http://www.laweekly.com/film/4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-2151224 |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days |last=Taylor |first=Ella |work=[[LA Weekly]] |date=19 December 2007 |accessdate=7 September 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908114213/http://www.laweekly.com/film/4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-2151224 |archivedate=8 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Gradea cited a 10,000 estimate.{{sfn|Gradea|2016|p=109}} Sanctions against contraception were also in place,{{sfn|Cardullo|2012|p=335}} and [[sex education]] was rare.{{sfn|Maierhofer|2017|p=161}} Following the [[Romanian Revolution|1989 Revolution]], abortion was made lawful, and subsequently unrestricted in the first 14 weeks.{{sfn|Maierhofer|2017|p=162}} ===Development=== The initial idea for ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'' was inspired by an anecdote from Communist Romania that director [[Cristian Mungiu]] had heard.{{cite web |url=http://www.4months3weeksand2days.com/blog/2007/05/17/interview-republik/ |title=Interview with Cristian Mungiu |publisher=Official website |last=Sandu |first=Ana Maria, ''RE:PUBLIK'' |date=25 May 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630011210/http://www.4months3weeksand2days.com/blog/2007/05/17/interview-republik |archivedate=30 June 2007 |language=Romanian |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} Though he had heard it from a friend 15 years prior to the film, the incident occurred five years before that, in 1987, a date that Mungiu noted in the screenplay.{{cite AV media |people=[[Cristian Mungiu|Mungiu, Cristian]] |date=2008 |title=Interview with the Director Cristian Mungiu |medium=DVD |publisher=[[Mongrel Media]]}} Mungiu, himself a decrețel (born in the time of Decree 770),{{sfn|Nasta|2016|p=169}} wanted to create a serious film focusing on the true story, which still affected him and felt tragic more than 15 years later. He conducted interviews with others who lived through the period, to determine if the experience was common. Aside from the anecdote, depicting the 1980s in Romania was appealing because he remembered the time, and "The attraction is for the stories that I know from that period. They belong to me. They belong to my generation".{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/atthemovies/txt/s2053849.htm |last=Stratton |first=David |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks & 2 Days Interview |date=2014 |work=[[ABC Online]] |accessdate=1 September 2017 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160511074221/http://www.abc.net.au/atthemovies/txt/s2053849.htm |archivedate=11 May 2016 |df=dmy-all }} He hoped that basing the story on a factual account would also distinguish it from previous [[Cinema of Romania|Romanian films]]: {{quote|I remember watching many [[propaganda film|propagandistic]] examples of Romanian cinema and thinking nothing like that ever happened to us. These people were talking the same language but still looked like aliens.{{cite magazine |date=17 January 2008 |last=Debruge |first=Peter |title=Cristian Mungiu |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]] |p=A18 }} }} In setting out to write the screenplay, he intended the focus to be less on the abortion, and more on the time and its people. He said, "it's also a film about responsibilities and decision-making". As he continued writing, he stated pushing a political point was not so much a factor in editing, as he opted not to delete potential scenes if they felt credible, asking "Would this reasonably have happened, and does it make sense to the story to keep it?"{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=18755277 |last= |first= |title='4 Months' Raises the Iron Curtain on Abortion |date=7 February 2008 |work=[[NPR]] |accessdate=1 September 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170902093329/http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=18755277 |archivedate=2 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Mungiu revised the screenplay numerous times during productions, creating 17 drafts. The major revision was the emergence of Otilia as the sole protagonist, while Găbița's part was reduced. In Mungiu's mind, Otilia had become determined to help Găbița because their shared life in the dormitory over four years would have created an emotional tie between them.{{cite web |url=http://www.indiewire.com/2009/12/decade-cristian-mungiu-on-4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-246089/ |last=Mungiu |first=Cristian |title=Decade: Cristian Mungiu on '4 Months, 3 Weeks, and 2 Days' |date=23 December 2009 |work=[[IndieWire]] |accessdate=28 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170628231957/http://www.indiewire.com/2009/12/decade-cristian-mungiu-on-4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-246089/ |archivedate=28 June 2017 |df=dmy-all }} The film was produced on a budget of under €600,000. ===Casting=== {| class="infobox" style="font-size:100%;" |- ! Actor ! class="unsortable" | ! Role |- | [[Anamaria Marinca]] | ... | Otilia Mihartescu |- | [[Laura Vasiliu]] | ... | Gabriela 'Găbița' Dragut |- | [[Vlad Ivanov]] | ... | Mr. Viarel Bebe |- | [[Alexandru Potocean]] | ... | Adi Radu |- | [[Luminița Gheorghiu]] | ... | Gina Radu, Adi's mother |- | [[Adi Cărăuleanu]] | ... | Dr. Radu, Adi's father |- | Mădălina Ghițescu | ... | Dora |- |} Casting took place during the autumn of 2006. Because of the extended takes, Mungiu sought actors who could remember large amounts of dialogue, and found that [[Vlad Ivanov]] was ideal for a 25-minute sequence.{{cite web |url=http://www.filmmakermagazine.com/archives/issues/winter2008/4months.php#.WVPoZ2jyvIU |last=Smith |first=Damon |title=Once Upon a Time in Romania |date=Winter 2008 |work=[[Filmmaker Magazine]] |accessdate=28 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170616200435/http://filmmakermagazine.com/archives/issues/winter2008/4months.php#.WVPoZ2jyvIU |archivedate=16 June 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Mungiu viewed [[audition]]s of many young women for the two protagonists. [[Anamaria Marinca]] had not worked with Mungiu before reading the screenplay, and found the story intriguing. She had performed on television, but had not appeared in a film before.{{cite web |url=https://archives.sfweekly.com/sanfrancisco/4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-director-cristian-mungiu-interview/Content?oid=2166203 |last=Foundas |first=Scott |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days Director Cristian Mungiu Interview |date=6 February 2008 |work=[[SF Weekly]] |accessdate=28 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170628232348/https://archives.sfweekly.com/sanfrancisco/4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-director-cristian-mungiu-interview/Content?oid=2166203 |archivedate=28 June 2017 |df=dmy-all }} On initially meeting Marinca, the director could not picture her in the lead role, but was won over when she began reading the first page of the screenplay. She had experience on stage, so the lengthy takes were agreeable to her. [[Laura Vasiliu]] also had stage experience.{{cite web |url=http://www.formula-as.ro/2008/820/lumea-romaneasca-24/laura-vasiliu-cred-in-povestile-fericite-9641 |last=Vasiliu |first=Laura |title=Laura Vasiliu - 'Cred in povestile fericite' |date=2008 |work=Formula A.S. |language=Romanian |accessdate=29 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908112104/http://www.formula-as.ro/2008/820/lumea-romaneasca-24/laura-vasiliu-cred-in-povestile-fericite-9641 |archivedate=8 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} ===Filming=== Filming began in October 2006, with the objective to complete it by May, so that it could be entered into the [[2007 Cannes Film Festival]]. After [[location scouting]] during the fall, most of the filming was done in [[Bucharest]], with some scenes filmed in a hotel in [[Ploiești]]. Bucharest in 2006 was no longer how it would have appeared in 1987, due to new windows and other additions to the historic buildings. Production designer Mihaela Poenaru drew on her recollections of the period to prepare the locations. The Mr. Bebe character was also given a red [[Dacia 1300|Dacia]] car.{{cite web |date=2014 |last=Grancea |first=Mihaela |title=Historical Context of Mungiu's Movie 432 |url=http://upm.ro/cci3/CCI-03/Hst/Hst%2003%2002.pdf |publisher=[[Petru Maior University of Târgu Mureș]] |accessdate=7 September 2017 |p=29 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908153513/http://upm.ro/cci3/CCI-03/Hst/Hst%2003%2002.pdf |archivedate=8 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }}{{refn|group=n|name="Dacia"|Mungiu once commented about the period: "the only car you can see on the streets is Dacia".{{cite web |url=http://cinema.usc.edu/events/event.cfm?id=12053 |last=Ago |first=Alessandro |title=Tales From the Golden Age |date=15 September 2011 |publisher=[[University of Southern California]] |accessdate=19 December 2017}} }} In several scenes, the indoor locations were so small that the camera had to be placed outside of the room. [[File:Dacia 1300 1977 Bulldogtreffen 2012.JPG|250px|thumb|A red [[Dacia 1300|Dacia]] was used in production.]] To highlight the emotional state of the characters, the film was shot in long [[take]]s, [[close-up]]s were avoided, and a [[film score|score]] was not used. In Mungiu's mind, this would "keep a proper distance from the subject and be honest with the story". Cinematographer [[Oleg Mutu]] opted for a minimalist approach, lighting the backgrounds to display items common in 1987 while attempting not to distract from the characters too much.{{cite AV media |people=Mutu, Oleg |date=2008 |title=Interview with the Director of Photography Oleg Mutu |medium=DVD |publisher=[[Mongrel Media]]}} Mutu and Mungiu had previously developed a formula of lengthy takes and [[medium shot]]s with the director's first feature film, ''[[Occident (film)|Occident]]''.{{sfn|Bazgan|2013|p=164}} Mungiu found the dinner scene to be the most difficult to shoot, as including a large number of actors in a long take made it difficult to focus. It took 17 attempts over five days to complete the scene. In one scene, the aborted fetus is visible on screen for approximately 14 seconds, the length it took for the actors to deliver the dialogue, with Mungiu opting not to edit out the shot since it "was part of the story".{{cite magazine |date=1 March 2008 |last=Porton |first=Richard |title=Not Just an Abortion Film: An Interview with Christian Mungiu |magazine=[[Cineaste (magazine)|Cineaste]] |p=37 }} The chute featured at the end of the film was constructed for the film, as there was not one at the location. The crew dropped bags of cabbage and potatoes to create the [[sound effect]]. Due to Mungiu saying Romania did not use streetlights in 1987, Mutu considered other ways to light the final scenes, where the camera would move with Marinca for 200 metres. Mutu set up lights from building roofs for this sequence, employing a rod and [[paper lantern]]s for the camera. ==Themes and interpretations== Academic Judit Pieldner summed up the plot as "the story of a friendship facing a moral test".{{sfn|Pieldner|2016|p=105}} Scholar Florentina C. Andreescu opined the two female protagonists share emotional loyalty, while in the wake of Mr. Bebe's abuses, Otilia becomes increasingly suspicious of Adi.{{sfn|Andreescu|2013|p=118}} Professor László Strausz said that the film emphasises the ways that Romania's abortion laws inflicted humiliations on the protagonists, particularly between people of differing authority and sex.{{sfn|Strausz|2017|p=126}} He argued that class and generational conflicts are presented in the dinner party scene, where the characters have more food than lower classes, discuss social issues such as conscription into the [[Romanian Armed Forces]], and treat Otilia as representative of the "new generation" that does not appreciate what it has been given.{{sfn|Strausz|2017|p=132}} Academic Claudiu Turcuș remarked that the dinner scene, where the characters look down on some careers and act as if smoking in front of one's elders is disrespectful, shows how regressive they are.{{sfn|Turcuș|2017|p=230}} [[Ovidius University]] author Ileana Jitaru credited the film for reconstructing "an entire communist class ideology which divided society into 'working class people' and 'intellectuals'". Jitaru specifically cited the dinner scene, where the conversation makes much of the divide between those with university degrees and those with none.{{sfn|Jitaru|2014|p=5}} The attendees boast about belonging to the middle class, and make denigrating comments about Otilia's rural origins.{{sfn|Strausz|2017|p=131}} The term "communism" is never mentioned,{{sfn|Turcuș|2017|p=230}} the existence of Decree 770 is only implied,{{sfn|Gradea|2016|p=109}} and dictator Nicolae Ceaușescu is never named. Despite this, communism is a major subject.{{sfn|Godeanu-Kenworthy|Popescu-Sandu|2014|pp=225–248}} Andreescu found that in many locations, one power is dominant; in some, the government, while in others, an underground power or [[Heterotopia (space)|Heterotopia]] forms.{{sfn|Andreescu|2013|p=116}} The hotel room where the abortion is performed becomes a location outside of the government's supervision. Mr. Bebe exploits this, boasts of the worth of his expertise and notes the risk he is taking, in order to extort the women for sex.{{sfn|Andreescu|2013|p=118}} Turcuș instead interpreted the scene as Mr. Bebe presenting himself as the "new man", sharing the women's legal peril and an openness to sexuality, while in fact being "the communist brute".{{sfn|Turcuș|2017|p=231}} ''[[Jump Cut (journal)|Jump Cut]]'' writer Constantin Parvulescu stated "''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'' provides an astute balance of [[Ostalgie|ostalgia]] and anti-communist memorial". Parvulescu elaborated that the beginning gives a view of place and possessions that could be nostalgic, but these become overruled by crisis in the communist society.{{cite web |url=https://www.ejumpcut.org/archive/jc51.2009/4months/ |last=Parvulescu |first=Constantin |title=The cold world behind the window: 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days and Romanian cinema’s return to real-existing communism |date=2009 |work=[[Jump Cut (journal)|Jump Cut]] |accessdate=31 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170901015530/https://www.ejumpcut.org/archive/jc51.2009/4months/ |archivedate=1 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Essayist Adriana Gradea suggested that silence is a theme of the film, and citizens of communist nations would use silence to endure and resist. This is seen at the end, where Otilia forbids further discussion of the abortion. The lack of a score can also be seen as contributing to sense of pending danger.{{sfn|Gradea|2016|p=112}} [[File:Última Cena - Da Vinci 5.jpg|250px|thumb|The dinner scene is accidentally reminiscent of the Last Supper.]] The fact that the characters live in poverty is reflected in a scene where Mr. Bebe accosts his mother for wanting to buy sugar.{{sfn|Nasta|2016|p=169}} When Otilia is searching for Mr. Bebe, there is also a line of people visible in the background queuing for food, reflecting the lack of food security in the 1980s.{{sfn|Strausz|2017|pp=130-131}} Additionally, the characters are often impolite towards each other. Mungiu explained that this was related to the poverty, saying "You need people in a society to have reached a certain standard of living before they can be polite". The bartering scenes reflect how corporate goods common west of the [[Iron Curtain]] were prohibited in Romania and were viewed as luxuries.{{sfn|Jitaru|2014|p=6}} The dinner scene is reminiscent of the [[Last Supper]]. Author Doru Pop acknowledged the differing number of characters and no male Jesus, but asserted that it is relevant to have a dinner while a tragedy is unfolding.{{sfn|Pop|2014|p=146}} Mungiu conceded that such similarities were accidental, and that once he appreciated the potential analogy during production, the filmmakers added a more focused view of Otilia to reveal her stress. ==Style== [[File:Desaturated blues and greens.jpg|thumb|An ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'' critic positively reviewed the [[colour scheme]], which academic Ileana Jitaru identified as including desaturated greys, blues and greens.{{sfn|Jitaru|2014|p=6}}]] Scholar Dominique Nasta saw the style as a "[[minimalism|minimalist]], 'less is more' line".{{sfn|Nasta|2016|p=169}} [[British Film Institute]] writer Ben Walters judged it "simple and rigorous, with scenes composed of only one or two shots". Walters remarked on "handheld, mobile, almost literally breathtaking" shots, and on the impact of still scenes.{{cite web |url=http://old.bfi.org.uk/sightandsound/review/4146 |last=Walters |first=Ben |title=Heartbreak Hotel: Film of the Month: 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days |date=6 June 2012 |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |accessdate=31 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170803003952/http://old.bfi.org.uk/sightandsound/review/4146 |archivedate=3 August 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Journalist Brian Gibson assessed the photography as "patient, alert, dogged in its observation of Otilia's endeavours".{{cite web |url=http://www.vueweekly.com/4_months_3_weeks_and_2_days/ |last=Gibson |first=Brian |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days |date=6 March 2008 |work=[[Vue Weekly]] |accessdate=31 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170901015448/http://www.vueweekly.com/4_months_3_weeks_and_2_days/ |archivedate=1 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Surveying the photography, academic Ileana Jitaru found "simple, austere and realistic compositions in which the [[black humour]] is a stylistic means of anchoring the theme(s)".{{sfn|Jitaru|2014|p=4}} Jitaru also commented on the colour scheme, observing "cold desaturated colours", particularly greys, blues and greens in the beginning.{{sfn|Jitaru|2014|p=6}} Additionally, the story, set during a single day, is related by [[Real time (media)|real time]] narrative in its scenes, although minutes or hours may separate the events in separate scenes.{{sfn|Rabiger|Hurbis-Cherrier|2013|p=61}} ''[[The Guardian]]''{{'}}s [[Peter Bradshaw]] interpreted the style as "a nightmare of social-realist suspense".{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2008/jan/11/worldcinema.drama |last=Bradshaw |first=Peter |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks & 2 Days |date=11 January 2008 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=6 September 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170907121855/https://www.theguardian.com/film/2008/jan/11/worldcinema.drama |archivedate=7 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} ''[[The Independent]]'' critic Jonathan Romney characterized it as "claustrophobic" in parts and an "intense [[realism (arts)|realist]] exercise".{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/4-months-3-weeks-2-days-15-769821.html |last=Romney |first=Jonathan |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks & 2 Days (15) |date=13 January 2008 |work=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=6 September 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170907030408/http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/4-months-3-weeks-2-days-15-769821.html |archivedate=7 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Despite this, he also believed that the hotel scenes communicate "a sense of almost supernatural horror", and asks of the noise heard after Mr. Bebe chastises his mother: "A backfire? A gunshot? Who can tell? But it lends the scene its bizarre, oppressive air of ill omen". Critic Peter Debruge declared the style "the antithesis of your well-lit, elegantly shot Hollywood movies — or the locally made films of Mungiu's childhood". Journalist Steven Boone said that while the film was well reviewed for "its bracing drabness, its ugliness, its lack of style", he believed it was "beautiful and stylized", because "it is ''alive'' and piercingly present-tense". He compared it with the films of the [[Dardenne brothers]].{{cite web |url=https://www.slantmagazine.com/house/article/a-miraculous-frame-4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-take-three |last=Boone |first=Steven |title=A Miraculous Frame: 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days: Take Three |date=25 January 2008 |work=[[Slant Magazine]] |accessdate=31 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170918073826/https://www.slantmagazine.com/house/article/a-miraculous-frame-4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-take-three |archivedate=18 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Journalist Lauren Wissot judged the story "a suspense thriller", comparable to the work of [[Alfred Hitchcock]]. She felt "heat" in each frame, writing "we're waiting for the bomb— the constant threat of imprisonment or death that defined life under Nicolae Ceaucescu".{{cite web |url=https://www.slantmagazine.com/house/article/time-warped-4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-take-two |last=Wissot |first=Lauren |title=Time Warped: 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days: Take Two |date=25 January 2008 |work=[[Slant Magazine]] |accessdate=31 August 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161016042448/http://www.slantmagazine.com/house/article/time-warped-4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-take-two |archivedate=16 October 2016 |df=dmy-all }} Aside from reflecting the length of the fictional pregnancy, the 4-3-2 form of the title creates the impression of rushed countdown reinforcing the thriller genre aspects, Gradea wrote.{{sfn|Gradea|2016|p=109}} Responding to analogies to the Dardennes' style, Mungiu said in 2008 that he had only seen their ''[[La Promesse]]'' (1996) but was now interested in seeing more, and that he had asked the brothers to attend a showing of his film. Mungiu compared his style more to those of [[Miloš Forman]] and [[Jiří Menzel]], though he said he was influenced more by certain films than by a director's general filmography. ==Release== [[File:Cristian Mungiu (2007).jpg|20opx|thumb|Director [[Cristian Mungiu]] at the 2007 [[San Sebastián International Film Festival]].]] The film debuted on the first day of the [[2007 Cannes Film Festival|Cannes Film Festival]] in May 2007.{{cite web |url=http://emanuellevy.com/review/4-months-3-weeks-2-days-1/ |last=Levy |first=Emanuel |authorlink=Emanuel Levy |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days |date=17 May 2007 |work=Emanuellevy.com |accessdate=28 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818091231/http://emanuellevy.com/review/4-months-3-weeks-2-days-1/ |archivedate=18 August 2017 |df=dmy-all }} At Cannes, [[IFC Films]] purchased distribution rights for the United States.{{cite magazine |date=29 May 2007 |last=McCarthy |first=Todd |title=Fest's heady 'Days' |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]] }} After the festival, distribution rights for 60 countries had been sold. In September 2007, it competed at the [[San Sebastián International Film Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/fipresci-grand-prize-munguis-4-149280 |first=Pamela |last=Rolfe |title=Fipresci Grand Prize to Mungui's '4 Months' |accessdate=18 June 2017 |date=4 September 2007 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170619024859/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/fipresci-grand-prize-munguis-4-149280 |archivedate=19 June 2017 |df=dmy-all }} That month, it also screened at the [[2007 Toronto International Film Festival]].{{cite web |url=https://www.straight.com/blogra/remembering-2007-toronto-international-film-festival |last=Caddell |first=Ian |title=Remembering the 2007 Toronto International Film Festival |date=26 August 2008 |work=[[The Georgia Straight]] |accessdate=28 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170628231858/http://www.straight.com/blogra/remembering-2007-toronto-international-film-festival |archivedate=28 June 2017 |df=dmy-all }} In its own country, it debuted at the [[Transilvania International Film Festival]] in June 2007, where it attracted long queues.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2007/jun/14/festivals |last=Bergan |first=Ronald |title=Just don't mention Dracula |date=14 June 2007 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=28 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171011130315/https://www.theguardian.com/film/2007/jun/14/festivals |archivedate=11 October 2017 |df=dmy-all }} With only 50 theatres in Romania, and the lowest rates of theatre attendance in the [[European Union]], a crew on a caravan toured 15 towns without theatres over 30 days for screenings that year.{{cite AV media |people=Avram, Sorin |date=2008 |title=1 Month with 4 Months, 3 Weeks, 2 Days |medium=DVD |publisher=[[Mongrel Media]]}} At [[Transylvania]], Mungiu was happy to see that Romanian viewers could comprehend the [[black comedy|dark comedy]]. Filmmaker Sorin Avram documented the caravan tour through [[Focșani]], [[Petroșani]], [[Călărași]] and other communities, and interviewed some of the audience of 17,584 people, who described it as shocking and disturbing.{{refn|group=n|name="Caravan"|Avram reported on 15 towns, with the most viewers in [[Constanța]] (1,982), followed by [[Bârlad]] (1,937) and [[Drobeta-Turnu Severin]] (1,747) and the fewest in [[Satu Mare]], (381), [[Călărași]] (593), and [[Reșița]] (814). }} Although the film won the Cinema Prize of the French National Education System at Cannes, protests by the [[Anti-abortion movements|anti-abortion movement]] led [[Ministry of National Education (France)|French Education Minister]] [[Xavier Darcos]] to consider banning it from French high schools. This raised concerns among French film industry workers about [[film censorship|censorship]].{{cite magazine |date=1 March 2008 |last=Porton |first=Richard |title=Not Just an Abortion Film: An Interview with Christian Mungiu |magazine=[[Cineaste (magazine)|Cineaste]] |p=38 }} Consequently, the proposed ban was dropped in July 2007, and an educational DVD using the film was made available for ages 15 and up.{{cite web |url=http://emanuellevy.com/comment/4-months-3-weeks-2-days-to-be-shown-in-french-schools-7/ |last=Levy |first=Emanuel |authorlink=Emanuel Levy |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks & 2 Days to be Shown in French Schools |date=10 July 2007 |work=Emanuellevy.com |accessdate=28 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170629011154/http://emanuellevy.com/comment/4-months-3-weeks-2-days-to-be-shown-in-french-schools-7/ |archivedate=29 June 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Television stations and an airline also wished to censor the fetus shot. In June 2008, the film was released on DVD in [[DVD region code#1|Region 1]] by [[Genius Products]] in the U.S. and by [[Mongrel Media]] in Canada, featuring interviews with the filmmakers and Sorin Avram's documentary ''1 Month with 4 Months, 3 Weeks, 2 Days''.{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-ca-also15-2008jun15-story.html |last=Murray |first=Noel |title=DVDs: '4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'; 'Burn Notice: Season 1'; 'Californication: Season 1'; 'Fool's Gold' and more |date=15 June 2008 |work=[[The Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=10 September 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910065750/http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-ca-also15-2008jun15-story.html |archivedate=10 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=https://www.thecoast.ca/halifax/4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days/Content?oid=970542 |last=McCarney |first=Lindsay |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days |date=19 June 2008 |work=[[The Coast]] |accessdate=15 October 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20181016034930/https://www.thecoast.ca/halifax/4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days/Content?oid=970542 |archivedate=16 October 2018 |df=dmy-all }} In [[DVD region code#2|Region 2]], [[Artificial Eye]] published a 2008 DVD with the interviews and Avram's documentary.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2008/may/25/dvdreviews.reviews |last=Kermode |first=Mark |title=The choice ... and the cost: 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days |date=25 May 2008 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=10 September 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910172717/https://www.theguardian.com/film/2008/may/25/dvdreviews.reviews |archivedate=10 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} ==Reception== ===Box office=== In 2007 in Romania, there were 89,000 admissions for ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'', making it the seventh most attended film in the country that year, and the most attended Romanian film.{{sfn|Higson|2016|p=196}} By 11 November 2007, it had over 300,000 admissions in France.{{cite web |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/film-mungiu-dc/4-months-1-palme-lift-filmmakers-profile-idUKN0816448320071109 |title='4 Months,' 1 Palme lift filmmaker's profile |last=Kilday |first=Gregg |date=11 November 2007 |publisher=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=29 September 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170929144318/http://uk.reuters.com/article/film-mungiu-dc/4-months-1-palme-lift-filmmakers-profile-idUKN0816448320071109 |archivedate=29 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} By 8 September 2008, [[IFC Films]] reported a solid financial performance for ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'' in the U.S., with a gross of $1.2 million.{{cite magazine |date=8 September 2008 |last=Kaufman |first=Anthony |title=IFC Films |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Daily Variety]] |p=A10 }} The film completed its run in May 2008. It made $1,198,208 in North America and $8,642,130 in other territories, for a worldwide total of $9,840,338.{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=4months3weeks2days.htm |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks, 2 Days |date= |work=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=28 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170831214502/http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=4months3weeks2days.htm |archivedate=31 August 2017 |df=dmy-all }} ===Critical reception=== {|class="wikitable sortable" style="float:right; margin:10px 10px 0px 10px; font-size:90%" |+Best of 2007 rankings |- !scope=col| List !scope=col| Rank ! scope="col" class="unsortable"| {{Abbr|Ref(s)|Reference(s)}} |- |scope=row| [[A.O. Scott]], ''[[The New York Times]]'' || {{sort|01|1st}} | rowspan="15" |{{cite web|url=http://apps.metacritic.com/film/awards/2007/toptens.shtml |title=Metacritic: 2007 Film Critic Top Ten Lists |accessdate=27 September 2010 |website=[[Metacritic]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120415171324/http://apps.metacritic.com/film/awards/2007/toptens.shtml |archivedate=15 April 2012 }} |- |scope=row| [[Dana Stevens (critic)|Dana Stevens]], ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' || {{sort|01|1st}} |- |scope=row| Liam Lacey and Rick Groen, ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' || {{sort|02|2nd}} |- |scope=row| Sheri Linden, ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' || {{sort|02|2nd}} |- |scope=row| Peter Rainer, ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]]'' || {{sort|03|3rd}} |- |scope=row| Manohla Dargis, ''The New York Times'' || {{sort|03|3rd}} |- |scope=row| Kirk Honeycutt, ''The Hollywood Reporter'' || {{sort|03|3rd}} |- |scope=row| Scott Foundas, ''[[LA Weekly]]'' || {{sort|03|3rd}} |- |scope=row| Wesley Morris, ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' || {{sort|03|3rd}} |- |scope=row| Carina Chocano, ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' || {{sort|03|3rd}} |- |scope=row| Ella Taylor, ''LA Weekly'' || {{sort|04|4th}} |- |scope=row| Kenneth Turan, ''Los Angeles Times'' || {{sort|04|4th}} |- |scope=row| Kevin Crust, ''Los Angeles Times'' || {{sort|05|5th}} |- |scope=row| Lisa Schwarzbaum, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' || {{sort|08|8th}} |- |scope=row| Ray Bennett, ''The Hollywood Reporter'' || {{sort|03|9th}} |- |} The film received an enthusiastic response from critics, earning a 96% approval rating and 8.4/10 average rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 139 reviews,{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/4_months_3_weeks_and_2_days/ |last= |first= |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days (2007) |date=7 February 2008 |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |accessdate=14 February 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161017034739/https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/4_months_3_weeks_and_2_days/ |archivedate=17 October 2016 |df=dmy-all }} while also earning a 97% rating on [[Metacritic]] based on 37 reviews.{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days 2008 |date= |work=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=28 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171220000000/http://www.metacritic.com/movie/4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days |archivedate=20 December 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Numerous critics also placed it in their top 10 films of 2007 or 2008. [[Roger Ebert]] awarded it four stars, commenting on the stupidity of the character Găbița and contrasting her to the title character of that year's ''[[Juno (film)|Juno]]'', but hailing the film as "a powerful film and a stark visual accomplishment".{{cite web |url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-2008 |last=Ebert |first=Roger |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days |date=7 February 2008 |work=Rogerebert.com |accessdate=28 June 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730113411/http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days-2008 |archivedate=30 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }} ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine's [[Richard Corliss|Richard]] and Mary Corliss described it as a "gripping, satisfying film" and particularly noted the use of minimalism and "formal rigor" as defining aesthetic characteristics.{{cite web |url=http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1623326,00.html |last1=Corliss |first1=Richard |last2=Corliss |first2=Mary |title=Three Twisty Delights |date=18 May 2007 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=19 December 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130824174908/http://www.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1623326,00.html |archivedate=24 August 2013 |df=dmy-all }} Jay Weissberg from ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' magazine said that the film was "pitch perfect and brilliantly acted... a stunning achievement". He added that the film shares a number of characteristics with other productions of the [[Romanian New Wave|New Romanian Cinema]], namely: "long takes, controlled camera and an astonishing ear for natural dialogue".{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2007/film/awards/4-months-3-weeks-2-days-1200558756/ |last=Weissberg |first=Jay |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks & 2 Days |date=17 May 2007 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=30 September 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171005152410/http://variety.com/2007/film/awards/4-months-3-weeks-2-days-1200558756/ |archivedate=5 October 2017 |df=dmy-all }} For ''[[The New York Times]]'', Manohla Dargis championed the direction, cinematography and lengthy takes.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/25/movies/25mont.html |last=Dargis |first=Manohla |title=Friend Indeed Who Doesn’t Judge or Flinch |accessdate=29 July 2017 |date=25 January 2008 |work=[[The New York Times]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730110108/http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/25/movies/25mont.html |archivedate=30 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Peter Bradshaw remarked on the sharpness of Otilia and the apparent naiveté of Găbița, but considered this is how their crisis could have affected them, and praised the film as "a masterpiece of intimate desperation". In ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'', Damon Wise gave it five stars, positively reviewing the cinematography, colour scheme, and the depiction of the black-market terror created when something is outlawed.{{cite web |url=http://www.empireonline.com/movies/4-months-3-weeks-2-days/review/ |last=Lee |first=Benjamin |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks And 2 Days Review |accessdate=16 July 2017 |date=29 December 2007 |work=[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170716170315/http://www.empireonline.com/movies/4-months-3-weeks-2-days/review/ |archivedate=16 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }} ''The Independent''{{'}}s Jonathan Romney named it a "masterpiece", acknowledging the description "Romanian abortion drama" would be off-putting for some viewers but defending it as "harrowing". Writing for ''[[Le Monde]]'', Thomas Sotinel called the film excellent and cited Marinca for an intense performance.{{cite web |url=http://www.lemonde.fr/cinema/article/2007/08/28/4-mois-3-semaines-2-jours-l-horrible-jour-de-gloire-d-otilia_948424_3476.html |last=Sotinel |first=Thomas |title='4 mois, 3 semaines, 2 jours': l'horrible jour de gloire d'Otilia |accessdate=16 July 2017 |date=28 August 2007 |work=[[Le Monde]] |language=French}} Jean-Baptiste Morain of ''[[Les Inrockuptibles]]'' remarked on the film's powerful emotions, and credited Mungiu with managing to do much with little.{{cite web |url=http://www.lesinrocks.com/cinema/films-a-l-affiche/4-mois-3-semaines-2-jours/ |last=Morain |first=Jean-Baptiste |title=4 mois, 3 semaines, 2 jours |accessdate=16 July 2017 |date=28 August 2007 |work=[[Les Inrockuptibles]] |language=French |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730113424/http://www.lesinrocks.com/cinema/films-a-l-affiche/4-mois-3-semaines-2-jours/ |archivedate=30 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Some sources view the film as indicative of a broader renaissance in Romanian cinema in the 2000s, particularly in light of other successful Romanian films. These include [[Cristi Puiu]]'s ''[[The Death of Mr. Lazarescu]]'', which won the ''[[Prix un certain regard]]'' at the [[2005 Cannes Film Festival]]; [[Corneliu Porumboiu]]'s ''[[12:08 East of Bucharest]]'', which won the ''[[Camera d'Or]]'' at the [[2006 Cannes Film Festival]]; and [[Cristian Nemescu]]'s ''[[California Dreamin' (film)|California Dreamin']]'', which won the ''Prix un certain regard'' at the 2007 Cannes Film Festival.{{cite web |url=http://www.worldnewsaustralia.com.au/region.php?id=137301®ion=3 |last= |first= |title=Romania shines at Cannes |date=28 May 2007 |work=SBS World News |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071020195547/http://worldnewsaustralia.com.au/region.php?id=137301®ion=3 |archivedate=20 October 2007 }}{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2008/jan/13/drama.worldcinema |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks & 2 Days |last=French |first=Philip |date=13 January 2008 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=19 December 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170402131741/https://www.theguardian.com/film/2008/jan/13/drama.worldcinema |archivedate=2 April 2017 |df=dmy-all }} {|class="wikitable sortable" style="float:right; margin:10px 10px 0px 10px; font-size:90%" |+Best of 2008 rankings |- !scope=col| List !scope=col| Rank ! scope="col" class="unsortable"| {{Abbr|Ref(s)|Reference(s)}} |- |scope=row| [[Stephen Holden]], ''The New York Times'' || {{sort|01|1st}} | rowspan="13" |{{cite web|url=http://apps.metacritic.com/film/awards/2008/toptens.shtml |title=Metacritic: 2008 Film Critic Top Ten Lists |website=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=27 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60eITgMHN?url=http://apps.metacritic.com/film/awards/2008/toptens.shtml |archivedate=2 August 2011 }} |- |scope=row| [[Mick LaSalle]], ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' || {{sort|03|3rd}} |- |scope=row| Rene Rodriguez, ''[[The Miami Herald]]'' || {{sort|03|3rd}} |- |scope=row| Scott Tobias, ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' || {{sort|03|3rd}} |- |scope=row| Noel Murray, ''The A.V. Club'' || {{sort|04|4th}} |- |scope=row| [[Richard Corliss]], [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] || {{sort|04|4th}} |- |scope=row| Robert Mondello, ''[[National Public Radio|NPR]]'' || {{sort|04|4th}} |- |scope=row| [[Kyle Smith]], ''[[New York Post]]'' || {{sort|05|5th}} |- |scope=row| [[J. Hoberman]], ''[[The Village Voice]]'' || {{sort|07|7th}} |- |scope=row| [[Anthony Lane]], ''[[The New Yorker]]'' || {{sort|08|8th}} |- |scope=row| [[James Berardinelli]], ReelViews || {{sort|09|9th}} |- |scope=row| V.A. Musetto, ''New York Post'' || {{sort|09|9th}} |- |scope=row| Marc Mohan, ''[[The Oregonian]]'' || {{sort|10|10th}} |- |} In 2009, ''The Guardian'' ranked it seventh in its "Best films of the noughties" list, surveying the past decade.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2009/dec/24/best-films-noughties-cristian-mungiu |last=Brooks |first=Xan |title=Best films of the noughties No 7: 4 Months, 3 Weeks & 2 Days |accessdate=28 June 2017 |date=24 December 2009 |work=[[The Guardian]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730105617/https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2009/dec/24/best-films-noughties-cristian-mungiu |archivedate=30 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }} ''The New York Times'' critic A.O. Scott also put the film seventh on his best of the decade list.{{cite web |url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/12/28/at-the-movies-best-of-the-decade-picks/37227 |last=Scott |first=A.O. |title='At The Movies' Best of the Decade Picks |date=28 December 2009 |work=[[TV By the Numbers]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091231133746/http://tvbythenumbers.com/2009/12/28/at-the-movies-best-of-the-decade-picks/37227 |archivedate=31 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} In 2015, ''The Guardian''{{'}}s Benjamin Lee identified it as his favourite film to win the ''[[Palme d'Or]]'', praising it as a success as a modern thriller.{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2015/apr/14/my-favourite-cannes-winner-4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days |last=Lee |first=Benjamin |title=My favourite Cannes winner: 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days |accessdate=16 July 2017 |date=14 April 2015 |work=[[The Guardian]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730104710/https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2015/apr/14/my-favourite-cannes-winner-4-months-3-weeks-and-2-days |archivedate=30 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Writing in his '' 2015 Movie Guide'', [[Leonard Maltin]] rated it three and a half stars, and called it "forceful" with a "matter-of-fact tone".{{sfn|Maltin|2014}} In a 2016 worldwide critics' poll conducted by [[BBC]], it was ranked 15th in the [[BBC's 100 Greatest Films of the 21st Century|100 Greatest Films of the 21st Century]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20160819-the-21st-centurys-100-greatest-films |title=The 21st Century's 100 greatest films |publisher=BBC |date=23 August 2016 |accessdate=20 September 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170131124228/http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20160819-the-21st-centurys-100-greatest-films |archivedate=31 January 2017 |df=dmy-all }} ===Abortion debate=== On its international release, the film became partially viewed through the lens of the [[abortion debate]], with [[Emma Wilson]] writing in ''[[Film Quarterly]]'' that [[IMDb]] user reviews were highlighting this and comparing it to ''[[Juno (film)|Juno]]''.{{sfn|Wilson|2008|p=18}}{{refn|group=n|name="Juno"|Despite perceptions, ''[[Juno (film)|Juno]]'' star [[Ellen Page]] said her film was not intended as anti-abortion.{{cite web |url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/article/298588 |title=Juno star has a mind of her own |accessdate=5 April 2008 |last=Howell |first=Peter |date=30 January 2008 |work=[[Toronto Star]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080331100902/http://www.thestar.com/entertainment/article/298588 |archivedate=31 March 2008 |df=dmy-all }}}} Wilson observed ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'' displayed the aborted fetus, comparable to the [[United States pro-life movement|U.S. pro-life movement]]'s use of such images, but argued the film was closer to [[pro-choice]] ideology in its focus on the law's harm to women. Wilson further argued that the true point was the loyalty of the two characters.{{sfn|Wilson|2008|p=18}} Mungiu said the fetus shot was not linked to the pro-life movement, as Romanians did not commonly use these depictions and the abortion debate was no longer prominent there. Anti-abortion protests comparable to those in the U.S. or Ireland did not occur in Romania until 2005, when the [[Romanian Orthodox Church|Orthodox Church]] commented on the matter.{{sfn|Maierhofer|2017|p=162}} Mungiu also declined to state his position on abortion, and said he attempted to keep his film and his personal position separate.{{sfn|Badt|2010|p=107}} Scholars Oana Godeanu-Kenworthy and Oana Popescu-Sandu argued the film was simply about communism, and the minimalism allowed for foreign audiences to see what they wanted, including a statement on the abortion debate.{{sfn|Godeanu-Kenworthy|Popescu-Sandu|2014|pp=225–248}} In the [[feminism in Canada|Canadian feminist]] magazine ''[[Herizons]]'', reviewer Maureen Medved judged ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'' to approximate a [[horror film]] in depicting the abuses that women suffer when abortion is illegal.{{cite magazine |date=1 January 2009 |last=Medved |first=Maureen |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days |magazine=[[Herizons]] |volume=22 |issue=3 |p=54 }} In anticipation of the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 U.S. presidential election]], ''Time'' critics Mary and Richard Corliss also cited the film to discourage electing a candidate opposed to ''[[Roe v. Wade]]'', saying the film revealed potential negative consequences.{{cite web |url=http://content.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1709046,00.html |last1=Corliss |first1=Mary |last2=Corliss |first2=Richard |title=How Not to Have an Abortion |accessdate=25 August 2017 |date=1 February 2008 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160729161943/http://content.time.com/time/arts/article/0,8599,1709046,00.html |archivedate=29 July 2016 |df=dmy-all }} In ''[[The Australian Feminist Law Journal]]'', [[Fiona Jenkins]] interpreted the story as a morally ambiguous argument that safe abortion services should be allowed, but that Otilia telling Găbița they will never talk about the matter reflects her "trauma not only of what she has undergone but what she has done".{{sfn|Jenkins|2009|p=63}} Peter T. Chattaway, writing for ''[[Christianity Today]]'', opined that "The abortion itself is handled in a way that could be seen to support both sides of the abortion debate", given the abuse to women, but also the portrayal of "the procedure's bloody aftermath".{{cite web |url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2008/januaryweb-only/4months3weeksand2days.html |last=Chattaway |first=Peter T. |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days |accessdate=29 June 2017 |date=25 January 2008 |work=[[Christianity Today]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170826170735/http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2008/januaryweb-only/4months3weeksand2days.html |archivedate=26 August 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Writer Waltraud Maierhofer also interpreted it as "not simply for or against abortion". Maierhofer commented a woman will consider many things in making a choice, including health, finances and what the potential child would face. In a discussion with Adi, Otilia indicates she would not be ready to enter a marriage and raise a family. Găbița's reasons are never said; it can be presumed she made the decision herself, though Maierhofer wrote at times she appears "irresponsible".{{sfn|Maierhofer|2017|p=161}} ===Accolades=== {{main|List of accolades received by 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days}} At the [[2007 Cannes Film Festival]], Cristian Mungiu became the first Romanian filmmaker to win the ''Palme d'Or'', the festival's highest honour.{{cite web |url=http://www.today.com/id/18895624/ns/today-today_entertainment/t/romanian-director-wins-top-prize-cannes/#.WVNTF2jyvIU |author=[[The Associated Press]] |title=Romanian director wins top prize at Cannes |accessdate=28 June 2017 |date=27 May 2007 |work=[[Today (U.S. TV program)|Today]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170628073142/http://www.today.com/id/18895624/ns/today-today_entertainment/t/romanian-director-wins-top-prize-cannes/#.WVNTF2jyvIU |archivedate=28 June 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Later, it became the first Romanian work to receive the [[European Film Award for Best Film]].{{sfn|Mallows|2012|p=42}} In its home country, it was nominated for 15 [[Gopo Awards]] and won nine, including Best Film.{{cite web |url=http://www.premiilegopo.ro/nominalizari/2008 |last= |first= |title=Nominalizari 2008 |accessdate=30 June 2017 |language=Romanian |publisher=Asociaţia pentru Promovarea Filmului Românesc |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818091720/http://www.premiilegopo.ro/nominalizari/2008 |archivedate=18 August 2017 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://www.premiilegopo.ro/castigatori/2008 |last= |first= |title=Castigatori 2008 |accessdate=30 June 2017 |language=Romanian |publisher=Asociaţia pentru Promovarea Filmului Românesc |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818091724/http://www.premiilegopo.ro/castigatori/2008 |archivedate=18 August 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Despite competing for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]], ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'' was not shortlisted, creating controversy among critics and online film fans, as it had won the ''Palme d'Or''.{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2008/film/awards/oscar-s-foreign-film-race-heats-up-1117979064/ |first1=Libby |last1=McCarthy |first2=Steven |last2=Gaydos |title=Oscar's foreign film race heats up |accessdate=18 June 2017 |date=15 January 2008 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730110845/http://variety.com/2008/film/awards/oscar-s-foreign-film-race-heats-up-1117979064/ |archivedate=30 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }} The controversy caused an [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences|Academy]] member to pledge nomination reform, though the category had often sparked criticism.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/01/18/AR2008011803357.html |first=Ann |last=Hornaday |title=Oscar Omissions Provoke Outcry, In Any Language |accessdate=18 June 2017 |date=19 January 2008 |work=[[The Washington Post]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170207103014/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/01/18/AR2008011803357.html |archivedate=7 February 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Mungiu later said the omission and subsequent furor brought the picture substantial publicity, and that the experience taught him that critics and festival juries have differing tastes from the Academy.{{cite web |url=http://ew.com/article/2012/12/14/prize-fighter-oscar-romania-foreign-film-cristian-mungiu-beyond-the-hills/ |last=Schou |first=Solvej |title=Romania's Oscar entry 'Beyond the Hills' director |accessdate=29 July 2017 |date=14 December 2012 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170730110029/http://ew.com/article/2012/12/14/prize-fighter-oscar-romania-foreign-film-cristian-mungiu-beyond-the-hills/ |archivedate=30 July 2017 |df=dmy-all }} ==Legacy== Following the Academy Award controversy, the Academy reformed its methodology of choosing Best Foreign Language Film nominees, allowing a committee of approximately 20 members to name three favourite candidates, balancing out a shortlist composed by a second committee made up of hundreds of voters.{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/feb/24/entertainment/la-et-oscar-foreign-20110224 |last=Zeitchik |first=Steven |title=Foreign-language Oscar nominees portray true grittiness |accessdate=25 August 2017 |date=14 December 2012 |work=[[The Los Angeles Times]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170919101138/http://articles.latimes.com/2011/feb/24/entertainment/la-et-oscar-foreign-20110224 |archivedate=19 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Steven Zeitchik of ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'' remarked the nominees of 2011 reflected the change, displaying unorthodox and challenging subject matter such as youth violence (''[[In a Better World]]''), incest by rape (''[[Incendies]]'') and particularly torture (''[[Dogtooth (film)|Dogtooth]]''). In 2013, ''[[The Wrap]]'' named Mungiu "The Man Who Changed Oscar’s Rules".{{cite web |url=http://www.thewrap.com/man-who-changed-oscars-rules-70591/ |title=The Man Who Changed Oscar’s Rules |accessdate=30 September 2017 |last=Pond |first=Steve |date=2 January 2013 |work=[[The Wrap]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170930173418/http://www.thewrap.com/man-who-changed-oscars-rules-70591/ |archivedate=30 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }} Mungiu reportedly planned ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'' to be the first in a loose series of films titled "Tales from a Golden Age".{{cite news|date=26 October 2007 |last=Griffin |first=John |title=Romanian director shoots for the soul |newspaper=[[The Montreal Gazette]] |p=D6}} Mungiu explained that "the golden age of Romania" is a term used nationally for Ceaușescu's final nine years in power, though he said people then suffered "shortages and hardship". He intended to make six [[short film]]s under the banner "Tales from the Golden Age", and then allow younger directors to take over the series.{{cite magazine |date=1 March 2008 |last=Porton |first=Richard |title=Not Just an Abortion Film: An Interview with Christian Mungiu |magazine=[[Cineaste (magazine)|Cineaste]] |pp=35–36 }} In 2009, he released a single film called ''[[Tales from the Golden Age]]'', following ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'' in depicting the Ceaușescu era and starring Vlad Ivanov.{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2009/film/markets-festivals/tales-from-the-golden-age-1200474749/ |last=Weissberg |first=Jay |title=Review: 'Tales From the Golden Age' |accessdate=25 August 2017 |date=20 May 2009 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170628231317/http://variety.com/2009/film/markets-festivals/tales-from-the-golden-age-1200474749/ |archivedate=28 June 2017 |df=dmy-all }} His next film, ''[[Beyond the Hills]]'' (2012), similarly depicted Romanian extremism, and Mungiu was inspired to make the cinematic adaptation after seeing the stage version in New York while promoting ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days''.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/03/movies/sacrifice-at-the-altar-of-intolerance.html?mcubz=3 |last=Rohter |first=Larry |title=Sacrifice at the Altar of Intolerance |accessdate=7 September 2017 |date=1 March 2013 |work=[[The New York Times]] |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908043322/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/03/03/movies/sacrifice-at-the-altar-of-intolerance.html?mcubz=3 |archivedate=8 September 2017 |df=dmy-all }}{{refn|group=n|name="Oscar"|Unlike ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'', ''[[Beyond the Hills]]'' was shortlisted for [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]] at the [[85th Academy Awards]].}} ==Notes== {{reflist|group=n}} ==See also== *[[List of Romanian submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] *[[List of submissions to the 80th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]] ==References== {{reflist}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin|30em}} * {{cite book |last=Andreescu |first=Florentina C. |date=2013 |chapter=The Changing Face of the Sacrificial Romanian Woman |title=From Communism to Capitalism: Nation and State in Romanian Cultural Production |publisher=Springer |isbn=1137276924 |ref=harv}} * {{cite journal |date=Spring 2010 |last=Badt |first=Karin |title=Interview with Cristian Mungiu |journal=Film Criticism |volume=34 |issue=2-3 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Bazgan |first=Nicoleta |date=2013 |chapter=Eastern Tales of Going West: The Micropolitics of Migration in Christian Mungiu's Occident (2002) |title=European Cinema after the Wall: Screening East-West Mobility |location=Lanham, Boulder, New York, Toronto and Plymouth |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |isbn=1442229608 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Cardullo |first=Bert |date=2012 |title=European Directors and Their Films: Essays on Cinema |location=Lanham, Toronto and Plymouth |publisher=Scarecrow Press |isbn=0810885271 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Deutscher |first=Penelope |chapter=Outside the Clinic: Precariousness and the Fetus |date=2017 |title=Foucault's Futures: A Critique of Reproductive Reason |location=New York and Chicester, West Sussex |publisher=Columbia University Press |isbn=0231544553 |ref=harv}} * {{cite journal |date=September 2014 |last1=Godeanu-Kenworthy |first1=Oana |last2=Popescu-Sandu |first2=Oana |title=From minimalist representation to excessive interpretation: Contextualizing 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days |journal=Journal of European Studies |volume=44 |number=3 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Gradea |first=Adriana Cordali |chapter=Communist Authoritarian Discourses and Practices in Romanian New Wave Cinema |date=2016 |title=Commanding Words: Essays on the Discursive Constructions, Manifestations, and Subversions of Authority |publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing |isbn=1443892130 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Higson |first=Andrew |chapter=Historical Films in Europe: The Transnational Production, Circulation and Reception of 'National' Heritage Drama |date=2016 |title=Screening European Heritage: Creating and Consuming History on Film |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |isbn=1137522801 |ref=harv}} * {{cite journal |date=June 2009 |last1=Jenkins |first1=Fiona |title=Queering Foetal Life: Between Butler and Berlant |journal=The Australian Feminist Law Journal |volume=30 |ref=harv}} * {{cite journal |date=2014 |last=Jitaru |first=Ileana |title=Cristian Mungiu, Auteur-Director 'Twenty Years After': Strategies of Translating the Past On Screen (4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days and Tales from the Golden Age) |url=http://litere.univ-ovidius.ro/Anale/documente-z/articole-2014/1-2014%20Jitaru.pdf |journal=Facultatea de Litere |publisher=[[Ovidius University]] |accessdate=7 September 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170908022950/http://litere.univ-ovidius.ro/Anale/documente-z/articole-2014/1-2014%20Jitaru.pdf |archivedate=8 September 2017 |df=dmy-all |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Maierhofer |first=Waltraud |date=2017 |chapter=When Abortion Was Illegal |title=Reproductive Rights Issues in Popular Media: International Perspectives |location=Jefferson, North Carolina |publisher=McFarland |isbn=1476669406 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Mallows |first=Lucy |date=2012 |title=Transylvania |edition=2 |publisher=Bradt Travel Guides |isbn=1841624195 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Maltin |first=Leonard |date=2014 |title=Leonard Maltin's 2015 Movie Guide |publisher=Penguin |isbn=0698183614 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Nasta |first=Dominique |chapter=Contemporary Romanian auteurs: Politics, irony, and reflexivity |date=2016 |title=The Global Auteur: The Politics of Authorship in 21st Century Cinema |location=New York, London, Oxford, New Delhi and Sydney |publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing |isbn=1501312650 |ref=harv}} * {{cite journal|date=2016 |last=Pieldner |first=Judit |title=Magic Realism, Minimalist Realism and the Figuration of the Tableau in Contemporary Hungarian and Romanian Cinema |journal= International Scientific Journal of Sapientia Hungarian University of Transylvania, Film and Media Studies |issue=12 |publisher=[[Sapientia University]] |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Pop |first=Doru |date=2014 |title=Romanian New Wave Cinema: An Introduction |location=Jefferson, North Carolina |publisher=McFarland |isbn=078647937X |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last1=Rabiger |first1=Michael |last2=Hurbis-Cherrier |first2=Mick |date=2013 |title=Directing: Film Techniques and Aesthetics |location=New York and London |publisher=Taylor & Francis |edition=Fifth |isbn=1135099200 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Strausz |first=László |chapter=A Modernist Approach to History: 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days |date=2017 |title=Hesitant Histories on the Romanian Screen |location= |publisher=Springer |isbn=3319552724 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Turcuș |first=Claudiu |chapter=Paradigms of Rememoration in Postcommunist Romanian * {{cite journal |date=Summer 2008 |last=Wilson |first=Emma |title=4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days: An 'Abortion Movie'? |journal=[[Film Quarterly]] |volume=61 |number=4 |ref=harv}} {{refend}} ==External
